result.execSummary:
The defendant Gregory A. Lindmeier was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • 2nd Degree Sexual Assault of Child, a class C felony, Wisconsin Statutes 948.02(2).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

superMiscConds.notes:
Pay court costs.   If the defendant is discharged from Extended Supervision with outstanding financial obligations, a civil judgment may be entered against the defendant and in favor of restitution victims and governmental entities for the balance due.
----------------------------------------

No contact with A.C.F. dob 03/28/2008 or C.M.F. dob 01/08/2004, their family, their residence or any place of employment. No contact with any minors. Not to possess or consume any alcohol or controlled substances.
----------------------------------------

Register as a sex offender with Wisconsin SORP and remain in 100% compliance with the conditions and expectations of the program.
----------------------------------------
Undergo any treatment assessments and participate in and follow thorugh with any recommended treatment.
----------------------------------------
Counseling as recommended by Probation Agent.
----------------------------------------
Provide biological specimen to state crime lab for DNA analysis, and pay DNA analysis surcharge.
----------------------------------------

records.addlTxt: Order for Defendant's Appearance at Department of Corrections for Pre-Sentence Investigation Report
Temporary Commitment form filed

9:02 am  Court in session.  Case called.  Appearances given.  ADA Haley Johnson appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Defendant Gregory A. Lindmeier in court, in custody with Atty Rebecca Hammock.   
Court is before the Court for a sentencing hearing.  Court makes record with regard to charge and maximum potential penalties.  Court understands defense is free to argue and the State will provide Court with general or pertinent information but will not make a specific recommendation as to sentence.  Court has reviewed the victim impact statements as well as the PSI and the sentencing memorandum prepared by the defense.  Atty Hammock has reviewed the PSI with Mr. Lindmeier and has no corrections.  Atty Hammock makes record as to photos that she provided to the State and the Court.  
9:04 am  Statement by James Jakubowski, Uncle and Godfather of defendant.  
9:06 am  Statements by Atty Johnson.  
9:10 am  Court makes record that victim's mother is present in courtroom but does not wish to speak.  
9:11 am  Argument by Atty Hammock.  9:19 am  Statement by defendant.  
9:20 am  Court proceeds with making its record and sentencing the defendant.  

SENTENCE:  
Total length of sentence:  14 years prison;  
8 years IC and 6 years of ES:  
424 days of sentence credit;  
NOT eligible for CIP or SAP;  

CONDITIONS OF ES:  
1)  No contact with A.C.F., dob 03/28/2008 or C.M.F., dob 01/08/2004, their family, their residence or any place of employment.  
2)  Register as a sex offender with Wisconsin SORP and remain in 100% compliance with the conditions and expectations of the program.  
3)  No contact with any minors.  
4)  Submit DNA same and pay surcharge.  
5)  Pay court costs and DOC supervision fees.  
6)  Undergo any treatment assessments and participate in and follow through with any recommended treatment.  
7)  Not to possess or consume any alcohol or controlled substances.  
8)  No to possess firearms.  

Court gives warns:  
1)  May not vote until civil rights are restored.  2)  May not possess firearms.  3)  May not work or volunteer with child (Sec. 948.13).  4)  May not possess body armor.  
9:37 am  Court in recess.
Sentencing Memorandum

records.descr: Notice and acknowledge of def voting ineligibility

records.addlTxt:
2:30 PM  FINAL PRE-TRIAL CALENDAR:  
DDA Haley Jo Johnson appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  
Defendant Gregory A. Lindmeier in court, in custody with attorney Rebecca Hammock.  
This case is scheduled for JT on Monday of next week.  Parties do have a plea agreement.  
State files an AMENDED INFORMATION charging Sexual Assault of a Child under 16 years of age.  The defendant will be pleading to that amended charge.  The defense is free to argue.  The State will not make a sentencing recommendation but will only advise the Court as to any relevant information.  Parties are not requesting a PSI.  Court advises that it will be ordering a PSI and inquires if the defendant is still willing to proceed.  Deft acknowledges wanting to proceed.  The mother of the victim is present in Court.  Court takes short recess to allow Atty Hammock to discuss the agreement further with her client.  3:17 p.m.  Case is recalled; same parties are present.  Attorney Hammock asks if the Court would consider a PSI with no recommendation being made by the Department in the PSI.  The Court is not comfortable dictating to DOC what should or should not be in its report.  The Court is willing to contact Supervisor Penny Vogt at DOC to inquire if they are willing ot prepare a PSI and not make a recommendation as to sentence.  Both sides agree with the Court's proposal.  

Atty Johnson makes record with regard to victim notification.  Court has plea colloquy with Mr. Lindmeier.  Defendant enters GUILTY plea to the charge in the Amended Information.  Court finds deft's plea to have been made freely, knowlingly, intelligently and voluntarily and adjudges the defendant guilty.  Court gives warnings with regard to possible deportation if not a citizen; firearms restriction; and voting ineligibility.  **PSI is ordered.  

Jury trial is CANCELED at this time.  Sentencing hearing scheduled for January 13, 2017 at 09:00 am.
Defendant Gregory A. Lindmeier in court, in custody with attorney Rebecca Hammock.  Haley Jo Johnson appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Minutes filed.

Defendant Gregory A. Lindmeier in court, in custody with attorney Rebecca Hammock.  Matthew R. Leusink appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Minutes filed.  Status conference scheduled for September 23, 2016 at 01:15 pm.

Defendant Gregory A. Lindmeier in court, in custody with attorney Rebecca Hammock.  Diane M. Donohoo appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Minutes filed.  Final pre-trial scheduled for October 12, 2016 at 02:30 pm.  Jury trial - 12 person scheduled for October 17, 2016 at 08:30 am.
Atty Rebecca Hammock

Transcript of Motion Hearing before the Hon. David M. Reddy on April 8, 2016
Court Reporter:  Mark Garvin
Notice of Videotaped Statment of a child, offer of proof, and request for hearing.

2:34 p.m.  Atty Haley Jo Johnson appeared for the State of Wisconsin. 
Deft Gregory A. Lindmeier in court, in custody with Atty Travis Schwantes.    
Matter is before the Court for a continued Motion hearing. 

3:52 pm  Court in recess.  
The Court will first address the "Harris" issue.  The additional information we now have is the Complaint from Waukesha County.  
Court has had a chance to more thoroughly review "Harris" and understands now that the Court found the evidence in that case not to be directly exculpatory but rather excuplatory impeachment evidence.  
Court asks Atty Johnson if she requests the information be disclosed?  Response by Atty Johnson.  
Court is requesting that Atty Johnson get this Information from Waukesha and provide it to Atty Schwantes.  
The Court will make the determination as to whether it can be used.  .  
Court next addresses the other acts Motion.  Court did review Atty Johnson's letter to the Court.  
Court will go through each of the paragraphs in the Affidavit.  

Paragraph 4:
Discussion between Court and Attys re:  acceptable purpose
Court will allow it in under motive and context 

Paragraphs 5 and 6:  
Discussion between Court and Attys re:  acceptable purpose
Court will allow it under motive and context

Court deals with 2nd portion of paragraph 5 (exposure)
Discussion between Court and Attys re:  acceptable purposes
Court will not allow that portion of paragraph 5

Paragraph 7:
Discussion between Court and Attys re:  acceptable purposes
Court believes it is pretty clear that it deals with motive and intent
Court will allow it under those 2 purposes.  

Paragraph 8:  
Discussion between Court and Attys
Atty Johnson reads portions of interview transcripts into the record.  
Atty Schwantes asks that it not be found as an acceptable purpose under the first prong.
Court thinks it is a signifcant connection with "poop"
Court will allow it for "context" only

Paragraph 9 is just a statement and Court does see it as an other act.  

STEP 2 (relevance) and STEP (3) Does probative value substantially outweigh the danger of unfair prejudice.
Some of the things to consider are nearness in time, place and circumstance.  
Response by Atty Johnson as to nearness in time.  
Response by Atty Schwantes as to nearness in time.  The only one that he thinks has a specific time is the one identified in #7.
Atty Schwantes indicates his argument isn't on the 2nd prong on any of these, but indicates his argument is on the third prong.  
Court makes findings as to nearness in time and the circumstance, distinctive traits involved, lack of frequency of these events within society.
Argument by Atty Johnson regarding step 3 (prejudice)
Court makes findings.  Greater latitude rule has to be taken into consideration.  
Court does not believe the concerns of the defense substantially outweigh the danger of unfair prejudice.  
The Defendant will have the opportunity to rebutt the evidence.  The Court will give a cautionary Instruction to the Jury.  
Court will allow the other acts evidence for all the reasons set forth.  

Shiffra-Green issue:  Dealing with counseling, treatment, psychiatric and psychological records of complaining witnesses (A.C.F)
Atty Schwantes is still asking for records relating to both children.  
Court asks how Atty Schwantes obtained the information referenced in his Motion.  
Atty Schwantes indicates most of the information came from the CPS report.  
Atty Schwantes is asking the court to review the records.  
Court believes Shiffra only deals with the victim and not with a witness.  
Atty Schwantes does not think the Court is wrong on this.  
Court does note that the witness could be considered an "uncharged" victim.  
Response by Atty Johnson that she had thought about charging it.  
She has no objection to Court doing Shiffra analysis as to both children.  

Court notes we are dealing with the relevancy component of the Shiffra Green standard.
Court understands that the Defense's position is that some of the conduct that is attributed to ACF in paragraph 11 could constitute PTSD and could be related to the prior case and not this case.  
Atty Schwantes argues that relevancy is for impeachment.  Response by Atty Johnson.  
3:36 pm  Continued discussion between Court and Attys.  
3:45 pm  Court needs something from Atty Schwantes tying up the symptoms that he knows of that could be related to PTSD and that could impair a victim's ability to recall or describe.  Court needs something that says this sort of projection from one perpetrator to another could occur over a 5 year period.  Response by Atty Schwantes.  Court will take this Motion under advisement unless and until Atty Schwantes submits any additional information.  

3:47 pm  One last matter is the State's Notice of Videotaped Statement of A.C.F.  Court asks Atty Schwantes if he is going to stipulate to use of the videotaped statement. Response by Atty Schwantes.  
Motion hearing continued to:  April 29, 2016 at 3:00 p.m.
Final Pre-trial on:  August 3, 2016 at 2:30 p.m.
Jury Trial on:  August 8, 9 and 10, 2016 at 8:30 am  

**04/26/2016 - Transcript FILED;  Court Reporter:  Mark Garvin  (df)
Defendant's Amended Motion for Disclosure of Recordings Describing prior Sexual Assault Against Witness & For In Camera Inspection of Treatment Records

Transcript of Motion Hearing before the Hon. David M. Reddy on 02/19/2016
Court Reporter:  Rhonda S. Boss
Notice of Videotaped Statement of a child, offer of proof, and request for hearing

3:31 pm  Court in session.  Case called.  Appearances given. 
Haley Johnson appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  
Deft Gregory A. Lindmeier in court, in custody with Atty Travis Schwantes.  
Matter is before the Court on 2 Motions.  
Court will first address the Motion for an In Camera review.  
Atty Schwantes explains that there are actually 2 components that are related but independent of each other. 
Atty Schwantes asks that the Court address the "Harris" issue first.  
Discussion between Court and Attys regarding access to the Waukesha County records.  
State is objecting to use of those records at trial.  
3:40 pm  Court takes short break to review the Kevin Harris court of appeals case.  
3:50 pm  Court is back on the record and the parties have had a chance to review the Harris case.
Discussion as to whether Waukesha County records are within the custody, possession and control of Walworth County?  
Argument by Atty Schwantes as to why he believes the information has to be disclosed.  
Court asks how can this information be used to challenge the credibility of witnesses? 
Response by Atty Schwantes.  
Court is asking what its authority is to order a DA's office in another county to turn over their records?
Continued argument by Attys Schwantes and Johnson.  
Court will give Atty Schwantes an opportunity to get information from the Waukesha County DA's office - criminal complaint, police reports.  
Atty Johnson is not comfortable requesting another DA's office entire file but believes they should share public records such as criminal complaints and police reports.
4:09 pm  Court asks if Atty Schwantes wants to get the information from Waukesha County DA's office before dealing with Shiffra Green?  
4:11 pm  Court next addresses the State's Other Acts Evidence.  Court goes through a Sullivan analysis.  
Discussion between Court and Attys as to purposes for which it is being offered by the State -- Intent and absence of mistake.  
Court believes what we are talking about here is whether or not it is even an other act?
Court asks Atty Johnson to see if there are other cases similar to this where this can be tied into these sort of acts. 
Court is going to readdress everything.  Motion hearing scheduled for April 8, 2016 at 02:30 pm.
